name: Confirmation Bias
summary: Favoring evidence that confirms existing beliefs.
definition: The tendency to selectively search for, interpret, and recall information that confirms prior beliefs.
classic_examples: Seeking news that aligns with your political views.
Remembering only studies that support your diet.

name: Availability Heuristic
summary: Judging frequency/likelihood by ease of recall.
definition: A mental shortcut that relies on immediate examples that come to mind, distorting probability estimates.
classic_examples: Fearing plane crashes after a widely reported accident.
Overestimating crime rates after sensational headlines.

name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
summary: Continuing due to past investment rather than future value.
definition: Escalation of commitment because resources already spent are irrationally treated as reasons to continue.
classic_examples: Finishing a bad movie because you paid for the ticket.
Staying in a failing project to 'not waste' prior effort.

name: Ad Hominem
summary: Attacking the person rather than the argument.
definition: A fallacy where rebuttal is directed against a person rather than addressing their argument.
classic_examples: ‘You’re no scientist, your claim is false.’
Discrediting a proposal by insulting the proposer.

name: Anecdotal Fallacy
summary: Using isolated personal stories as decisive evidence.
definition: Reasoning from a small number of personal experiences rather than systematic data.
classic_examples: “My friend smoked and lived to 95, so smoking isn’t harmful.”
“It snowed this week, so global warming is fake.”

name: Appeal to Irrelevant Authority
summary: Citing expertise from the wrong domain.
definition: Using testimony from a figure who is not an expert in the relevant field to support a claim.
classic_examples: “This actor says the supplement works, so it must.”
“A famous entrepreneur endorses a medical treatment.”

name: Hot-Hand Fallacy
summary: Believing success streaks in random events will persist.
definition: Attributing momentum to outcomes of independent events and expecting the streak to continue.
classic_examples: “I won twice in a row, I’m ‘hot’; I’ll win again.”
Assuming a stock will keep rising because it rose yesterday.

name: Base Rate Neglect
summary: Ignoring prevalence rates when judging probability.
definition: Underweighting prior probabilities (base rates) relative to individuating information.
classic_examples: Assuming a positive test means disease without considering false positives.
Claiming self-driving cars are safer because most crashes involve humans.

name: Tu Quoque
summary: Deflecting criticism by accusing hypocrisy.
definition: Responding to an argument by pointing out that the arguer fails to act consistently with the argument.
classic_examples: “You litter too, so your anti-littering point is invalid.”
“You’ve made mistakes, so your critique doesn’t count.”

name: Bandwagon Effect
summary: Adopting beliefs because many others do.
definition: Conforming to popular opinion or behavior as a cue for correctness or desirability.
classic_examples: “Millions use it, so it must be the best.”
Voting for the leading candidate to be with the majority.

name: Straw Man
summary: Misrepresenting an argument to refute a weaker version.
definition: Substituting a distorted or oversimplified claim for an opponent’s position to make it easier to attack.
classic_examples: “You want smaller class sizes? So you hate teachers.”
“They propose dietary guidelines; they want to control our plates.”

name: Slippery Slope
summary: Claiming a small step inevitably leads to catastrophic outcomes.
definition: Arguing that an initial move will trigger an inevitable chain of events without establishing the causal necessity.
classic_examples: “Allowing this exception will end the entire system.”
“Legalizing X will inevitably cause societal collapse.”

name: Cherry Picking
summary: Selecting only favorable data and ignoring the rest.
definition: Omitting inconvenient data points to create a misleading impression of support.
classic_examples: Highlighting best months of returns while hiding losses.
Citing only studies that support the claim.

name: Post Hoc (False Cause)
summary: Assuming causation from mere sequence.
definition: Inferring that because B followed A, A caused B, without ruling out confounders.
classic_examples: “The policy started, then crime rose; the policy caused it.”
“I wore lucky socks and we won.”

name: False Dilemma
summary: Presenting limited options as the only possibilities.
definition: Framing an issue as a choice between only two alternatives when more exist.
classic_examples: “You’re either with us or against us.”
“Adopt this policy or the economy fails.”

name: Circular Reasoning
summary: Using the conclusion as a premise.
definition: An argument where the conclusion is assumed in the premises; it restates rather than proves.
classic_examples: “This book is true because it says so.”
“He’s trustworthy because he says he is honest.”

name: Appeal to Emotion
summary: Manipulating emotions to win an argument.
definition: Substituting affective arousal for relevant reasons or evidence.
classic_examples: Sad imagery to sell a policy without data.
Fear-based messaging to push a product.

name: Red Herring
summary: Introducing an irrelevant issue to divert attention.
definition: Changing the subject to a tangential matter to distract from the point at hand.
classic_examples: Answering a budget question by talking about patriotism.
Shifting from product safety to ‘jobs created’ when challenged.

name: Burden of Proof
summary: Placing proof on the wrong side of the dispute.
definition: Demanding opponents disprove a claim that has not been substantiated.
classic_examples: “Prove ghosts don’t exist.”
“Until you refute it, my claim stands.”

name: Appeal to Tradition
summary: Arguing something is right because it’s customary.
definition: Supporting a claim by asserting it aligns with long-standing practice rather than presenting reasons.
classic_examples: “We’ve always done it this way, so it’s best.”
Rejecting innovation solely because it’s new.

name: False Equivalence
summary: Presenting two unequal things as morally or logically the same.
definition: Arguing that two positions are equivalent due to superficial similarities while ignoring relevant differences.
classic_examples: Equating minor misconduct with systemic abuse.
Treating isolated errors as equal to widespread harm.

name: Composition Fallacy
summary: Assuming the whole has the properties of its parts.
definition: Inferring that what is true of individuals must be true of the group or aggregate.
classic_examples: “Each player is a star; the team must be unbeatable.”
“Every component is cheap, so the product is cheap.”

name: Division Fallacy
summary: Assuming parts have the properties of the whole.
definition: Inferring that what is true of a group or aggregate must be true of its individual members.
classic_examples: “The company is profitable; every team must be thriving.”
“The average is high; each case must be high.”

name: Equivocation
summary: Using a key term with multiple meanings within the same argument.
definition: Shifting meanings of a term mid-argument to create an illusion of logical connection.
classic_examples: “Light things aren’t dark; feathers are light; feathers aren’t dark.”
Using ‘theory’ in the casual sense to dismiss a scientific theory.

name: Gambler’s Fallacy
summary: Believing a deviation will be corrected in the short run.
definition: Expecting an opposite result because the opposite has not occurred recently in independent events.
classic_examples: “After five reds, black is due.”
Expecting a coin to land heads because it has been tails several times.

name: Survivorship Bias
summary: Focusing on successful cases while ignoring failures.
definition: Drawing conclusions from visible successes without accounting for the unseen non-survivors.
classic_examples: “These founders dropped out and succeeded; school is useless.”
Analyzing only winning funds to claim a strategy works.
